Fields.DialogueText: Well, what's all this, Capitano?
I overheard from some of the officers that you are quite the coffee aficionado. We've been out of stock for a while now...
... But we received a few bags in our most recent resupply, and I thought I'd share. Sit down and have a cup.
That's so kind of you, Capitano. Thank you so much for your thoughtfulness.
I haven't had any yet. How does it taste?

Fields.MenuText: Does it leave something to be desired?
Finding coffee during wartime is difficult enough. Finding good coffee during wartime is a tall order.
I've never seen anyone work so diligently to conceal a look of disgust.

Fields.DialogueText: It took me a few seconds to adjust to the flavor, that's all.
I have no doubt. Please, don't mistake my silence for a lack of appreciation.
I apologize. I had hoped my reaction wouldn't have been so... apparent.
It can't be that bad, can it? Here, I'll give it a try.
I wouldn't suggest that! It's awfully—
—Bitter.
Now that my esophagus has been stripped of its internal lining, I have a new plan. Why don't we hurl this stuff at the Morganas during our next battle?
Well, we have a few approaching from the south. Shall I grab the bags?
If you wouldn't mind.
@BATTLE
Here, here, Capitano, please sit down.
What? Why, what's going on? What—
Calm down, I assure you, everything is fine. I so appreciated your thoughtfulness in offering me coffee earlier, that I decided to contact a few friends in Ethiopia.
Is that coffee? It smells... it smells so much better than that coffee we had before.
That's because this is authentic Ethiopian coffee, Capitano. I give you my word, your esophagus will still be intact after drinking this. Here's your cup.
Axum...

Fields.MenuText: This is the best coffee I've ever had.
I might need to petition Command to bring this in for the rest of the crew. We'd win the war within the month if we were all drinking this.
I'd waive all your other duties if you would only bring me a cup of this every morning.

Fields.DialogueText: It is tasty, isn't it? So rich and flavorful.
I'm sure my friends in Ethiopia would be thrilled at the increase in business.
I think those are your tastebuds speaking, but I appreciate the sentiment.
You really like this, don't you? Making coffee for other people?
I like coffee, and I like the conversations one has over coffee. So, yes! Certamente.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. I'm afraid the rest of the coffee will have to go to waste.
Not to worry - there's more where that came from.
I'm happy to hear it.
@BATTLE
Axum! There you are—I've been looking for you.
Capitano! What's going on?
A couple of VIPs will be coming aboard in the near future. A retired admiral and his daughter. I heard both of them enjoy coffee...
Aha! Is this you asking me if I might make some for them?

Fields.MenuText: This is me asking you if you would make some for them.
As your captain, I could order you to make some for them. But at this moment, yes, I'm requesting as much.
And me. Don't forget about me.

Fields.DialogueText: I would be happy to, Capitano.
You are my Capitano, and whether it be a request or an order, I will do as you ask.
Ha! I like your honesty, Capitano. Yes, I will make the VIPs–and you–some coffee.
Thank you, Axum. I'd like you involved with my discussions with the Admiral as well—he has some questions about the Belles.
I would be happy to participate.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. You'd better get to your station.
Yes, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Admiral Bertrand, this is our resident Belle, Axum.
You're the first Belle I've seen with my own eyes, Mademoiselle. It's a pleasure to meet you!
You have quite the handshake, Admiral! The pleasure's all mine. I know our quarters are tight, but I hope your stay is comfortable.
And who is this?
My daughter. Margot! Come over here and introduce yourself.
Capitaine, Mademoiselle Axum. It's... a pleasure to meet you both. I'm Margot Bertrand.

Fields.MenuText: She seems shy, doesn't she?
Odd that a man as verbose as the Admiral would produce a daughter as meek as this girl.
She's quite the talker, isn't she?

Fields.DialogueText: Is this her first time aboard a submarine? I'd be a little withdrawn myself, with the sounds this ship makes.
Is it, though? Many children are noticeably different from their parents.
Oh, hush, Capitano. Don't make fun of the girl.
Now, Admiral, Margot, I've heard you both appreciate a good cup of coffee. I've brought a very special blend today, which I'm sure you'll find appealing.
*ALARM*
Is that... the alarm?
Those Morganas won't be content until they've deprived me of every cup of coffee you put in front of me, Axum.
My apologies, Admiral, Margot. Per favore, help yourself in our absence, and we will return as soon as we can.
@BATTLE
Signorina Margot? What are you doing over here, by the sick bay? Are you not feeling well?
Hmm? Oh, Axum. No, I'm, well... no, I'm fine. I was just... um.
Are you sure you're all right? You look a little pale. Should I grab one of the doctors?
No! I mean, no. I'm fine. I'll just... I'll just be on my way.

Fields.MenuText: Is everything all right? Margot looked... not particularly well.
I'll need to have a word with her father. She needs to know she shouldn't be hanging around the sick bay.
She's about as awkward as they come, isn't she?

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but she refused to tell me what was on her mind.
Then talk to her, Capitano. She's nearly a grown woman - certainly capable of understanding what you have to say.
Be nice, now.
I think she might have been watching the doctors.
Okay. You think she might have a crush on one of them?
Considering our doctors are all a solid thirty years older than the girl, I doubt it.
Captain, we have Morganas headed in from the west.
Sound the alarm. We'll be there in a moment.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I don't have any problem with that. It's being in their way that we can't afford.
Okay, what am I missing?
She just seemed so intent.

Fields.MenuText: I dunno. I had some crushes when I was a teenager that wouldn't make a lot of sense to an outside observer.
I take your point.
Well, as long as she's not in anybody's way, it's none of our business.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I need to know every single detail now.
Yeah, I don't think that's going to happen.
Mm.
You don't sound like you agree.
She's our guest, Capitano. Surely that means we're obligated to see to her happiness.
We're obligated to keep her fed and healthy. I don't think we're entitled to examine her every waking-
Signorina Margot! There you are!
I'm fine, Mademoiselle Axum, I promise.
... But something's going on.
N-no...

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure, Margot? You did seem upset.
Axum. This is none of our business.
Well, I'm convinced.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree, Margot. Please, if there's anything we can do to help, let us know.
Capisco. I just... Margot, I just want to be sure you're okay.
You're so helpful, Capitano.
I-I was watching the doctors. I... want to be one.
Well, that's wonderful! You didn't have to act so bashful, our medics are a friendly bunch. They won't mind.
They might not, but my father would. He's very... traditional about these things. He thinks women ought not to work, and refuses to pay for me to attend university.
That must be very-
*ALARM*
We'll talk about this after the battle, Margot. Don't give up hope.
@BATTLE
Are you all right? You seemed upset earlier.
Oh. Oui. I'm... that is, I....

Fields.MenuText: Agreed.
*sigh*
We'll talk about this if you want to talk about it. Otherwise, we'll leave you alone.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course she wants to talk about it. Look at her!
Let's just get to the bridge, okay?
Axum? Oh, Capitaine, hello!
Margot! I'm so happy to see you! You'd be amazed how difficult it is to find a person in quarters this cramped.
Axum, I know you mean well, but please don't tell my father about our earlier conversation.
... If you insist, I won't. But I would encourage you to reconsider.
What?
You want to receive an education that will allow you to help others. Your father loves you, and I'm sure he recognizes the good of doctors in the world.
I'm sure we could convince him to come around to the idea. Right, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: Without a doubt.
An admiral should be able to see the benefits of such a career path.
Wait, what now?

Fields.DialogueText: See, like I said!
Well spoken, Capitano.
Very helpful, Capitano.
We will help you, Margot. Convincing authority figures to change their preconceived beliefs is tricky... but I'm sure it can be done.
She isn't talking about me.
No! The Capitano is a commendable authority figure, of course. I was referring to...
We have Morganas inbound, Captain.
We'll be to our stations shortly.
What do you say, Margot?
I say... if you think you can help me, I'd be a fool to turn you down. Thank you!
Molto bene! Let's meet after the battle.
@BATTLE
Ah! Capitano, look!
We weren't going to.
Axum. I know you haven't had a lot of experience with families, but in my experience parents don't generally react well when perfect strangers step in to tell them how to raise their kids.
It's not a matter of how she's raised! She's already raised! It's a matter of-
I'm not saying I don't agree with the principle. I'm saying we could do more harm than good.
Capitano, I have faith that we won't.
In the meantime, Axum...
So, how do you plan on actually convincing the admiral, Axum? I don't expect this to be an easy sell.
We must approach this situation thoughtfully. We can't chastise the admiral for his previous or current behavior. We must show him the benefits of changing his behavior in the future.
You still haven't actually answered how.
*SLAM*

Fields.MenuText: That's... a big book, Axum.
Where did you get that book?
Ah, so you're going to use that book to beat the Admiral senseless.

Fields.DialogueText: I know! Impressive, isn't it?
One of the officers gave it to me.
Not literally. Figuratively, however...
This is my planning book. It's blank right now, but I'm going to fill it with the information we need to convince the admiral to send Margot to medical school.
It will help us organize and strategize.
You sound awfully confident.
What can I say? I'm an optimist!
*ALARM*
Still feeling optimistic?
Always, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Capitano! Do you have a moment?
Sure. Step inside.
Grazie. I thought we should talk about the Margot project - we obviously don't have very much time before she and the Admiral leave the ship.
Right. Did you happen to bring coffee?
Ah. No, I'm sorry. I can go get-
No, it's fine.
Listen. I wouldn't ask if you hadn't made me part of your master plans here, but - why are you so preoccupied with this?
What, Margot wanting to be a doctor? Because we can make a difference. And it's the right thing to do.
Yeah, okay. But I don't see you inserting yourself into the crew's lives like this, and I guarantee you that some of them have family problems that would break your heart.
But they're adults. And they *know* that they can come to us for help.
I think... I don't think anyone has ever told Margot that she doesn't just have to spend her life submitting. I think having friends now could really help her a lot.
Mm. I could note that there's a difference between being friends and promising to singlehandedly change family dynamics that have formed over a lifetime. Maybe even generations.
You think this is a bad idea?

Fields.MenuText: No. I just want to go into it with our eyes open.
Maybe. But some of my best ideas are bad.
Actually, yes.

Fields.DialogueText: Capisco. I promise, we'll do this right.
... What does that even mean?
Heh.
Okay, regardless, we seem to be committed now.
Please, give me a chance to convince you otherwise.
Well, yeah. I haven't kicked you out of my quarters, have I?
Margot, Margot! Look at all of these!
Wha...?
They're university brochures. I asked around on the ship, and a few members of the crew had them. They were thinking about their own university choices, for after the war.
These brochures have all sorts of useful information that I thought could prove very helpful. Have you given any thought as to what school you'd like to attend?
I've considered a few universities...
Excellent. It's important that, when we talk to your father, you have concrete information you can present to him. Where you want to go, the cost... you understand.
I think it's strategically wise to take your father's own tastes into consideration when making these decisions. He'll be more likely to support you if you appeal to his preferences.
Appeal to his...?
Axum...

Fields.MenuText: We have Morganas headed this way!
Get to your station.
Give the girl room to breathe and get ready to fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Sì, Capitano!
I'm on it.
She has plenty of room to breathe! You do, don't you?
Don't worry, Margot. Give it some thought, and I'll be back to help before you know it.
@BATTLE
Um... oui?
There you are, Axum!
Ciao! You're looking chipper.

Fields.MenuText: She really is looking much happier.
I hope this means the sea air agrees with you.
She's actually cute when she doesn't look like death.

Fields.DialogueText: Giusto! See, we're helping.
It does, actually. Merci!
I'm going to ignore that comment...
Axum, I've decided on a university. I've considered the subject thoroughly, and have decided on Johns Hopkins, in Baltimore.
I know it's very competitive, but my test scores and grades have been second to none. I'm confident that, with my father's support, I'll be admitted.
It's a wonderful school, Margot. Good luck.
Actually...
What?
What?
I was thinking... your father attended Oxford, didn't he? And they have one of the best medical schools in the world.
I wonder, if you were to go there instead, if your father wouldn't be more supportive.
Margot?
W-what did I say? What happened?
*ALARM*
We need to go.
@BATTLE
Margot?
Hello there, Captain.
Hiding from Axum?
You won't tell her, will you?

Fields.MenuText: Your secret is safe with me.
Regardless of how pushy she might be, I won't lie to her if she asks.
You picked a terrible hiding spot. She'll probably find you here in the next few minutes.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine.
Oh, of course, Capitaine.
This really is a terrible hiding spot, isn't it?
Capitano! And there you are, Margot. I'm sorry to interrupt, but we have Morganas headed this way.
I'll be right there.
@BATTLE
I bet this isn't what you were expecting when your father dragged you out to sea.
... At least people are talking to me. I'm usually just in the way.
Not here. Honestly, if you don't find yourself a university, Axum might just try to recruit you.
It wouldn't be the worst thing in the world. Doing my part for the war effort.
It's up to you. If you want to be a doctor, though, I vote you give it a shot. It's a pretty good way of doing your part.
... Oui. I think so too.
Okay.
So, do you want me to ask Axum to leave you alone about Oxford?
Non. It's okay. It's just... this isn't exactly the first time in my life I've said I wanted to do something and then someone told me I should make my father happy instead.
Yeah, I get it. And, honestly, there's something to be said for leading with Johns Hopkins and saving Oxford as a compromise choice, if you can live with it.
All that said, if you're going to ask him to pay tuition, you might want to pick your fights. You know him better than I do.
Hasn't he started telling you how to run your ship yet?
Heh. No comment.
I'm assuming that if you went to a French university he'd be a more active part of your education than you'd really prefer, by the way. Correct me if I'm wrong.
Not... so much.
Axum?
Margot, come in! Would you like some coffee?
Non, that's fine. Don't go to any trouble.
Margot, I'm sorry for forcing Oxford on you like that. Sometimes, I can become very focused on the optimal way of doing something.
I allowed that focus to override what you wanted, when you were the one I promised to help in the first place.
It's all right, Axum. You were right.
Hmm?
Becoming a doctor is what is most important to me, and Oxford has a fine medical school. If you think that's the best way to convince my father, I'll follow your lead.
Are you sure?
Absolutely. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to do more research on Oxford. I can't be too prepared.
You're a girl after my own heart, Margot.
Oh, ciao, Capitano. Was that your handiwork I saw there?

Fields.MenuText: Well, I knew where the two of you were coming from, and thought I might have some success as mediator.
It's a captain's job to keep the peace on the ship.
No, I told her she should join the circus. Seems to've backfired terribly.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps you should look into counseling after the war.
Well, you did a commendable job.
*giggles*
Captain, we have Morganas sighted to the southwest.
Shall we be on our way?
Certamente.
@BATTLE
Now that we've decided on Oxford, what do we do next?
I would be willing to be that Axum has a plan.
We need statistics.
Statistics?
Sì. I've studied your father's career, his way of making decisions. I think he needs data, evidence in front of him, if he's to understand that the world is changing.
And where do you plan on finding said statistics, Axum?
Well, that's where your help comes in, Capitano. I've composed a list, here, of surveys that track the number of women in the workplace.
I'd like to put in an order for copies of several of them.

Fields.MenuText: That seems easy enough! I'll put in the order.
These surveys won't be too costly, will they?
Of all the odd things a Belle could make me order...

Fields.DialogueText: Fantastico. Thank you, Capitano.
No, they're quite reasonable, I assure you.
I'm sure, down the line, Belles will convince you to order far odder things, Capitano.
What can I do while we wait for the surveys to arrive?
Start writing out what you want to say to your father, once we finally bring him this information. Make use of the planning book as you do.
You'll need to be as concise and confident as you can possibly be.
*ALARM*
Ready, Axum?
Sì, Capitano. Always.
@BATTLE
All right, I put in the orders for four workforce surveys, three prominent articles written recently about women in the medical field, all of Margot's school transcripts...
You ordered my transcripts? How do you even know where I went to school?
I always do my research, Margot!
You know, Capitaine, she's-

Fields.MenuText: Amazing?
Intense?
You don't even have to say it.

Fields.DialogueText: She is amazing, but that wasn't quite the word I was searching for.
A little bit, yes.
Ahem.
We should have all of the materials here before we know it. Then, the real fun begins.
I think you and I have different definitions of the word fun, Axum.
Probably so.
Capitaine, what's this book?
Brave New World? Have you not heard of it? It came out a few years ago. One of the officers must have been reading it.
Something tells me it isn't the sort of book your father would approve of.
My father has never read fiction. I doubt he's even heard of it. It looks... interesting.
*ALARM*
I will never get used to the sound of the alarm.
Andiamo, Capitano. To the bridge!
Lead the way.
@BATTLE
Ah, look! The shipments have arrived - here are all the materials we'll need to convince your father, Margot.
That certainly is a lot more boxes than I imagined.
We couldn't just order one section of each survey. We had to order the surveys in their entirety. We'll need to go through these materials and clip out the portions we want to use.

Fields.MenuText: Between the three of us, we should find what we need.
Maybe I'll ask a few off-duty crew members to help.
We? Who exactly are you referring to, Axum?

Fields.DialogueText: That's the right attitude, Capitano!
Although their help would certainly be appreciated, I'm sure the three of us are up to the task!
You. Me. Margot. Though I'm fairly certain you already knew that.
It's all a little overwhelming... but it's exciting, too. Shall we get started?
Sì - certamente. Margot. You take those boxes on the north side of the room, I'll take these, here, and...
Captain? Axum? We've spotted incoming Morganas. The alarms will sound at any second.
Dannazione.
Don't worry, I'll get a head start while the two of you are gone.
Thanks, Margot.
We'll be back before you know it.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Let's not overpromise, Axum.
We'll be as prepared as we can be, anyway.
I just want it understood that we're not storing all this crap in my quarters.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not overpromising. I'm very, very confident.
The Capitano is joking.
The Capitano needs to be able to walk around in the dark without breaking a toe on a crate of records.
This is more paper than the reports sitting on my desk...
You know, locating the statistics we need sounded intimidating at first. But now that we're in the thick of it, I find I'm enjoying myself.

Fields.MenuText: It's nice to have mindless activity now and then, isn't it? It lets the brain relax.
You know, I really should be checking on the crew...
My hand has been cramped around the scissors for hours. I'm not sure I'll recover full motion after this.

Fields.DialogueText: It is, isn't it? And we can converse while we're working - that's my favorite type of work.
You checked on the crew a few minutes ago, and they were fine. Si calmi, Capitano.
Di calmarsi, Capitano. Your hand will relax if you give it enough rest.
What I like most is seeing the information contained in these statistics. I knew the world - and the workplace - was changing, but not to this extent.
It's all rather remarkable.
You're feeling a little more confident, aren't you?
I have to admit, I am. There are so many girls, like me, in medical school right now. There's no good reason why I shouldn't be there as well.
I'm sure that if we approach your father respectfully, and show him all of this evidence we've collected, he'll come to understand that as well.
They don't look sorted.
No, they are. Those go toward the back - oh, except for that article, put that in the front.
*ALARM*
I guess it's that time again.
Hold down the fort while we're gone, Margot!
Mais oui, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
Okay. If anyone wants me to put clippings into this enormous doorstop--
Planning book.
I stand by my original choice. That said, I'm available for arranging.
Sì. Grazie! These clippings here, for a start...
I don't know about all this. Now that Margot's seen the glamorous life of a Neutrality Fleet captain, she may be reconsidering the whole medical school--
Look at the planning book. It's so... beautiful.
It's absolutely packed. I don't think you could stuff more information into it if you tried.
Is that a challenge?

Fields.MenuText: No, it's not a challenge. Although I find it amusing you would take it as one.
No, Axum, it's just a figure of speech.
Yes, it is. Let's do this.

Fields.DialogueText: You know I'm of the mind that you can never have too much information.
Si, lo so. But still...
You sound awfully confident...
So, what's left for us to do?
You have what you're going to say to your father all planned out? The exact words?
I do!
Then all that's left is to make the setting as palatable to your father as possible. Clearly, we're in a submarine, so there's only so much we can do on that front.
But I could make some of the coffee he finds so delicious. And Margot, you start thinking of anything else we could do. If your father likes it, we'll include it.
My father's fairly picky... but I'll see what I can come up with.
And I guess I'll just-
Fight the incoming Morganas?
Y'know, if we loaded that book into a torpedo tube, it could probably punch through a solid inch of-
@BATTLE
Don't even joke about it.
... Should've seen that coming.
What's all this, Margot?
Well, I thought that since we would be having coffee during the conversation with my father, I could come up with a list of my father's favorite foods.
That's an excellent idea.
He loves breakfast foods; eggs, sausage, toast, that sort of thing. I know the supplies your cooks have onboard are limited, but do you think this could work?

Fields.MenuText: We'll figure something out.
This would cut into the crew's protein rations...
Funny, I took him for a sushi sort of man, myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Wonderful, thank you, Capitano.
As long as you're not cutting into the crew's alcohol rations, I assume they'll be fine.
You're so proud of your sarcasm, aren't you, Capitano?
Well, with that set, then...
What?
Are you ready to talk to your father?
Heheh... Uh...
Don't lose your courage, Margot. You've come this far.
I know. But you've met my father - I could have all the courage in the world, and I would still find him intimidating.
Well, the Capitano and I will be with you throughout it all. You have nothing to fear.
Non. Merci, I'd be very grateful to have you both there. It won't stop him from shouting, but perhaps it'll help me stay brave.
*ALARM*
What if the alarm goes off while I'm talking to my father?
We'll... ask the Morganas to hold off for a few minutes. I'm sure they wouldn't mind.
... Right.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
If you want us there, that is.
Why wouldn't she?
Not all awkward family moments are improved by having random passers-by stick their noses in.
... Oh. Certamente.
Father!
There you are, Margot! I've hardly seen you since we stepped foot on this boat. You haven't been pestering the officers, have you?
N-non...
Admiral Bertrand, your daughter has been an absolute delight. The Capitano and I have thoroughly enjoyed getting to know her.
Well, I'm glad to hear it. I sometimes worry about how quiet she is...
Father? I was wondering, well... I've arranged for a meal for the four of us. You, me, the Captain, and Axum. You'll come, won't you?
Margot, I'm sure the Captain has duties to attend to. You shouldn't expect--

Fields.MenuText: I've already cleared my schedule, Admiral.
I do have duties I probably should be attending to...
Normally, that would be true. But as soon as I heard breakfast food would be served, I couldn't resist.

Fields.DialogueText: All we're waiting on, Admiral, is to hear from you.
The Capitano is joking! Joking, I assure you, Admiral. What an oddball sense of humor you have, Capitano.
That's hardly surprising...
Is that so? Well then, I'd be delighted to attend. And good for you, Margot, taking the initiative to put such a thing together.
Th-thank you, Father.
Captain, we have more Morganas headed in.
We'll be right there.
A presto, Admiral!
@BATTLE
Margot, you've hardly eaten any of your eggs. That isn't like you... what's wrong?
Admiral, Margot is just...
Father... Father, look at this book.
*SLAM*
That's a big book.
My apologies, I didn't mean to hit the tabletop so forcefully.
What is it?
It's... my evidence. Inside, you will find pages of news articles and statistics, all detailing the growing numbers of women in the workplace...
... And specifically in the medical field. The good they're doing in the world, and the respect with which they're viewed.
What is this?
I believe she just told you, Admiral.
No, what is this? The three of you. Is this why I haven't seen you, Margot? You've been conspiring with these two?
Just look at the book, Father, I think you'll see-
No, Margot. You know my thoughts on the subject, and they have not changed. Captain, rest assured, your superiors will hear of this.
*ALARM*
Come on, Axum. We need to go. Pardon us, Admiral. Margot.
@BATTLE
*gently kicks Axum under the table*
Maybe she doesn't have enough salt?
Noted. Would you care for more coffee?
Absolutely not! I can't believe you would have the audacity to--
The audacity to help a clever, respectful young woman write a report? If you're proposing to torpedo my career over it, you might want to read it first.
Capitano...
You're not about to out-glare me, sir. You sure you don't want more coffee?
I'm so sorry for causing trouble between you and the Admiral, Capitano. I was so sure he'd listen to what Margot had to say...
Do you really think he'll talk to your superiors about this?
The Admiral is retired. The Protection Force values his insight, but he has no say in personnel matters.
That's a relief. Still, I'm so sorry.
... Am I entitled to ask a nosy question?
Certamente. I'd say you've more than earned it.
Do you think that your insistence on helping Margot get into medical school was at all fueled by... How do I put this? Your own background with dismissive authority figures?
The Italian government isn't exactly known for its inclusiveness.

Fields.MenuText: I should add that, if I'm entitled to ask a nosy question, you're entitled not to answer.
If it *is* an issue, it's better that you confront it sooner, rather than later.
I mean, they are a bunch of bigoted, authoritarian-

Fields.DialogueText: No, it's all right, Capitano.
I agree - if an issue exists, it should be dealt with.
They also happened to free the slaves of Ethiopia. The issue is more complex than it seems.
I... I don't know to what extent my feelings regarding Italy - with some of our own admirals - have influenced my dealings with Margot and her father.
But the fact that I don't know means that there's some soul-searching left to do.
Captain, we have Morganas headed in from the east.
Axum, are you ready to fight?
Sì, Capitano. Of course.
@BATTLE
Stop. If I hadn't already made this clear, I wouldn't have been involved in this business if I hadn't thought it was worth doing.
But you did repeatedly make the point that getting involved in a family discussion-
Stop. Seriously. It's fine.
That's an awfully serious look you have on your face, Axum. Are you soul-searching?
No, not right now. I just can't stop thinking about Margot. I gave her hope, hope that she would be able to attend university, and I let her down.

Fields.MenuText: There might be reason for her to hope yet.
Don't sound so miserable, Axum. Not when there's still a chance for victory.
Your plan was a bit of a disaster, but we still might be able to salvage the situation.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't imagine how.
I won't sound so miserable when you tell me how that's possible.
Are you trying to make me feel better or worse?
There's always been a Plan B at the back of my mind. We've been assuming Margot needs her father's money to attend medical school, but...
What are you saying? You think we could find her, what? A scholarship?
One or two or seven. You saw her school transcripts. I'm sure grades that high would catch the eye of one school or another.
But that would require her to defy her father. Do you really think she would go that far?
There's only one way to find out.
*ALARM*
After the battle?
Of course.
@BATTLE
Capitaine?
Margot, how are you doing?
My father and I will be departing soon, and I wanted to stop by and thank both you and Axum.
Really?
Yes, really. I know things didn't work out they way we'd hoped, but you two supported me. You helped me stand up to my father, which has never happened before.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry we couldn't convince your father to come around.
Your father is... an intimidating man, for sure.
You're remarkably mature for a teenager, Margot. Possibly more mature than I am.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. He is so set in his ways.
Actually, he's mellowed in his retirement. I heard he regularly used to make his officers cry.
You're an odd one, you know that, Capitaine?
Axum is in there, isn't she? You wouldn't mind if I just slipped in and told her a quick-
Actually... you can't.
I... can't?
Not right now, no. I promise, you'll have an opportunity to see her before you and your father leave, but right now she's in the midst of researching a very important subject.
Oh! I understand. Of course.
Capitano! We have Morganas headed this way. Margot...don't go in that room, all right?
I won't, but...
We'll see you in a bit, Margot.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? Axum? Those are some rather large smiles on your faces.
We wanted to give you these, Margot. As a farewell gift.
It's... a large stack of papers.
Read them!
W-what... these are all...
Every page has information regarding different scholarships you are eligible to apply for.
With the help of those scholarships, you would be able to attend university without your father's assistance.
Axum's been working tirelessly to put that information together for you, Margot.
Don't give me all the credit. The Capitano was a huge help as well.
I... thank you, both of you, but I can't take these.
Margot...
If my father even saw these... I'm sorry, I can't.
Capitano, we have to do something...
*ALARM*
Later, Axum. We need to go.
Va bene, va bene.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Not the most impressive gift at first glance, I know.
Seemed like the natural gift to remember us by, all things considered.
Damn. I meant to grab the souvenir cap.

Fields.DialogueText: Your father already disembarked, Margot?
He did. I just wanted to tell you both goodbye before I left. And apologize - I know the two of you have worked so hard on my behalf...
No apology is necessary, Margot.
We saw someone in need of help, so we helped. It's the decent human thing to do.
You two are so kind. Thank you.
Here, we brought you a present. A little different from our previous attempt.
Brave New World?
You said it looked interesting.
Hopefully it will keep you entertained during your travels.
I'm sure it will. Capitaine, Axum - see you again, someday?
Sì, of course! Let me know when you're coming, and I'll have our best coffee at the ready.
You're welcome on this submarine any time, Margot.
When do you think she'll notice that you inserted all of those scholarship pages into the back of the book?
I'm not sure. But she has them. And should she decide she wants to use them, they'll be there for her.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. You ready?
As always.
Axum...

Fields.MenuText: I couldn't imagine a better friend to have by my side.
What an extraordinary woman.
